A worthy history and sociology documentary! We all know the last few lines stated by Courtney Brown and Dr. Carl Taylor to be true. When we deny the connections and thin lines between politics, corporations, the law and the streets we miss understanding even how we individually stand in the mix of how America and the world operates - whether, for better or worse, we make the right decisions for ourselves or our families, one way or another as we maneuver each of life's complexities and dichotomies - these being in the past or moving forward. Nothing is ever as it seems. R.I.P. The Crowd Pleaser and I hope Courtney Brown, Sr. stays alright!

A film that shows us the inner workings of the drug trade in the inner city, this one being Detroit.  The drug trade gives the operators and their families a way out of the inner city and their children become lawyers and businessmen.  A comparison is made to other historical purveyors of mood elevating substances (alcohol) who then became the richest and most respected families of our country.  The film should be seen by sociology students and well as students of social work or counseling as it would help them see a culture from a different perspective.

I love the movie!! because!! it show not only the street level drug dealers and how much money can be made! but it shows how the government and deals drugs and how everything is connected!! the only sad part of the movie is that the end! mr Jackson son!! said his father never told  on anyone!  I wonder how he think his father got busted when he was dealing with the French connection and stars he was dealing with from Motown all illuminati and paying off judges and court case and lawyers to win!! nothing is free!. burt he has a right to his free speech !!and respect on my part! great movie and you can learn alot111

I have got to say I really enjoyed this movie. A few months ago I was searching for the movie "Detroit" and it was not out yet so several other movies on the topic came up instead. I saved them to my list and have been watching! This is truly a compelling story. Heroin kills people, we all know that so it is uncomfortable that this group of heroin selling drug dealers are so likable, generous, and family focused. Even Tony Soprano has nothing on them, (according to them) they stayed out of the sex and violence and ran their business like any other business man running a legal business would. As someone from Detroit we are all looking to say "nice" things about Detroit so there is that cringe aspect to it, like this is a story about major drug dealers in  Detroit can we get a story about someone doing something good and legal?? But that thought is passing because they do put everything in context. The movie starts way back at the beginning so the viewer knows these guys did not just start selling drugs because people from Detroit sell drugs, that's what they do, it's that type of place etc.. it really gives a background into how the city started breaking down and deteriorating, the destruction of thriving black neighborhoods, it touches on all of that. Also as someone from Detroit, that Detroit feeling comes through in this movie, I do not know exactly how to put it but it's like this-- I have been mugged, then I have been mugged at gunpoint, I have had my car broken into countless times BUT I have had complete and total strangers help me out big time, stuck in the snow, one guy jumps in the driver  seat of my car and steers, the other guy pushes - and just like that, a single vulnerable woman stuck in the snow and all these guys did was help, they could have backed up and driven around me- but they didn't. I was broke down on the side of 94 @Van Dyke, I cannot tell you how many people stopped to help, some people offered to push me by hand up the on on ramp so I could get to a gas station, I couldn't let them do that. Or even just the countless people that will just start talking to you just in the name of being friendly. A story about two men who run the biggest drug operation in the city, selling the deadliest of drugs -who are loving husbands and fathers, and coach little league, and pay for their kids college in full -- that  is a real Detroit story for me.
Loving seeing stories that are untold. ( at least untold to me)
This was very interesting because this was a part of black hisyory no one ever talked.

I watched this documentary.  Went back and re watched the ending several times.  Everyone knows a good story always has a beginning a middle and an end.  I still don't know how this story ended.  What happened to Eddie Jackson.  I had to google him after and I believe he died in 1995. If it's the same Eddie Jackson.  But, I didn't find any info on how he died or if he died in prison or what.  I feel like I was left hanging.

Great documentary. I loved it. Eddie Jackson could have been a great leader in politics if he weren't such a great leader in the drug business.

An interesting documentary about Eddie Jackson who was the top drug retailer in Detroit during the '70s. The documentary is worth watching but the narrator was not a match. If you can tolerate the narrator's voice this one will entertain you and teach you about another chapter in Detroit's underworld history.
I loved it! It was good to hear the real stories from individuals that actual lived it.
